Prescribing discharge medication & documentation requirements ............................... 9
Issuing discharge medication (TTAs) to the patient .................................................... 16
Introduction
Medication-related issues at transitions of care are well documented, including mostly recently by the WHO Patient Safety Challenge: Medication Without Harm (WHO, 2019).

This policy outlines safe standards of practice and the process of preparing medication for discharge from the clinical setting (ward/unit etc.). The discharge medication process involves checking and reconciling medicines against the prescribed discharge medication list. However, it is more than simply handing over ‘to take away' (TTA) medicines to our patients.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to ensure our patients are always:
supplied with the correct medication, labelled safely and accurately in accordance with their finalised discharge prescription;
supplied medicines legally by our staff;
provided an appropriate quantity of medicines for their condition, avoiding unnecessary waste, accumulation or inappropriate overuse of some high-risk medicines after discharge;
given written medication information that is complete, accurate and supportive for their ongoing care;
given counselling on their medicines, supporting adherence to their medicines
regimens.

This policy outlines service expectations for the discharge process with respect to medication and medicines-related information. It does not cover the wider discharge from hospital that is covered by separate Trust and legacy site policies.

This policy applies to all patients who are discharged from an inpatient setting within the Trust to an external place of care (regardless of whether services are provided by an external organisation or the MSE Trust).
The same expectations within this policy apply for the nurse/midwife-led issue of pre-packed medicines from an outpatient appointment, in all clinical area settings.
Definitions

table_items.text: The letter accompanying the drug list with which the patient is discharged. This is usually completed using an electronic system and depending on site may also be known as ‘eDH', ‘Lorenzo' ‘ICE' ‘EDL' electronic discharge letter or a discharge prescription.
Essex Partnership University NHS Foundation Trust
Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust Bridging Service
North East London NHS Foundation Trust
Verification process by the pharmacist that the medicine is clinically appropriate for the patient, within the scope of the information available to review.
Pharmacy-On-Wheels. The Trust near-patient pharmacy discharge service.

A service which allows Trust pharmacy staff to send an electronic message to a patient's nominated community pharmacy at discharge. This is to provide recommendations or information as part of the community pharmacy Discharge Medicines Service.
A community interest company (social enterprise) that provides health and social care services in the community
Prescription Tracking System used by pharmacy.

To take away/ to take out – specifically the discharge medication, as per the discharge prescription. This term is also used interchangeably in practice to mean the discharge prescription as well (i.e. doctor has ‘written the TTA')

Medication which has been pre-labelled with directions provided by the pharmacy department for issue from a clinical area. It may be supplied to patients either on discharge or as a hospital attender. Labels must be completed on supply with patient name, date and any dosage instructions.
The Trust electronic prescribing and medicines administration system used on general inpatient wards.

data.text: Role & responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse and site Directors of Nursing or Chief Medical Officer and site Medical Directors as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning discharge medication & use of TTA packs.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's accountable officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Medical Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site Medical Directors that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated discharge medication issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site & Divisional Medical Directors
Ensuring that there is policy compliance by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated discharge medication issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site pharmacy leadership team, that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated discharge medication and TTA-pack issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Director of Nursing & Deputy Directors of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated discharge medication and TTA-pack issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for discharge medicines management across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
The Chief Pharmacist delegates this responsibility to the site Pharmacy Heads of Department and site Pharmacy Operations Managers for delivery by their teams.
Prescriber of discharge medication
Providing a clear, complete and accurate discharge prescription and any other required documents (i.e. controlled drug paperwork etc.) in a timely manner;
Submission of all required referrals needed for safe discharge (i.e. anti- coagulation clinic);
Reconciling and acting on any remaining medication discrepancies compared to the patient's listed medication regimen on admission, and accounting for all changes;
Providing reasons for all medication changes (new, stopped, changed) or declaring no changes to medication on the discharge summary;
Informing pharmacy and nursing/midwifery staff immediately when a discharge prescription has been written and is ready for processing;
Actively engaging with the clinical pharmacy team in managing discharge issues in a timely way;
Provision of medicines counselling in line with this document.
Discharge Co-ordinators
Escalating complex discharge needs to pharmacy team in a timely way;
Providing clear, accurate and complete discharge information to the pharmacy team;
Supporting medication discharge arrangement in alignment with Trust medication policies and associated standards.
Discharging Registered Nurse/Midwife
Timely requesting of written discharge prescriptions to pharmacy using the correct hospital site process;

Providing complete and clear discharge information to the pharmacy team at the point of requesting a discharge prescription; including patients with specific discharge needs (i.e. new placement, transfer to bridging team etc.);
Monitoring of the pharmacy Prescription Tracking System for completed discharge prescriptions;
Dispensing of pre-labelled packs, where available, and second checking of these in line with this document, where appropriate and permitted;
Accurately checking and providing only correct medication, additional items and patient information for discharge in line with the discharge prescription (TTA);
Removing, with consent, medicines no longer required on discharge in line with this document and MSEPO-21128 Administration of Medicines Policy;
Highlighting to the prescribing doctor if any discrepancies exist between the prescription and the patients' own medication;
Obtaining advice from pharmacy staff if patients' own medication cannot be easily identified (e.g. blister packed medication);
Provision of medicines counselling in line with this document;
Finalise completion of the electronic discharge letter and printing the final discharge summary (with prescription) to give to the patient, where possible;
Completing, in full, the patient medication discharge checklist;
Documenting all checks and issues of medicines on discharge within the patient health record (i.e. on drug chart / copy of discharge summary);
Placing a printed copy of the discharge summary in the patient health record, where available.
Healthcare assistant working under the discharging registered nurse/midwife. These may be known as Discharge Facilitators (depending on site)
Where demonstrated competency and signed off, operating in a ‘discharge support' role:
Assisting in the assembly of items required for the TTA and working with pharmacy to support the smooth processing of medication requirements;
Highlighting any potential issues immediately to the registered nurse/midwife and pharmacy team;
Monitoring of the pharmacy Prescription Tracking System for completed discharge prescriptions.

Whilst the registered nurse/midwife may delegate aspects to a competency assessed healthcare assistant, the responsibility for supply of the correct medication, in its entirety, against the valid prescription remains solely with the registered nurse/midwife.
Pharmacy Team (Pharmacists, Pharmacy Technicians and Pharmacy Assistants)
Supporting medicines reconciliation and informing prescribing medical/surgical teams of any discrepancies where identified (as per MSEPO-21090 Medicines Reconciliation Policy);
Co-ordinating medicines supply and pharmacist clinical screening to facilitate discharge within the required timeframes;
Highlighting to prescribers and nursing/midwifery staff for TTAs that need prescribing when required;
Where requested to review a TTA, confirming patient's existing route of supply of regular medication to be used post-discharge;
Acting as a point of contact to support intermediate discharge teams and community medicines management teams;
Processing the TTA to enable patients who have consented for the Discharge Medicines Service (via PharmOutcomes) for onward referral, where appropriate;

Communicating outstanding issues to prescribers, and nursing staff, as appropriate, in a timely manner. This will be carried out in a consistent manner in accordance with pharmacy departmental procedures;
Supporting the provision of medicines counselling in line with this document, where available;
Tracking of prescriptions on the Prescription Tracking System;
Dispensing of medication in line with departmental procedures.
Pharmacist (additional to pharmacy staff role above)
Clinically screening the drug chart, including a review of the drug history and identified discrepancies, resolving where possible and/or referring to prescriber for resolution;
Authorising discharge prescriptions submitted to pharmacy for new medicines or changes; ensuring clear transfer of accurate and complete information to the GP;
Ensuring relevant information is entered within the PharmOutcomes submission to the Discharge Medicines Service on discharge, in accordance with pharmacy departmental procedures;
Making appropriate records on Wellsky ePMA in line with pharmacy departmental procedures to support accurate statistical reporting.
Discharge planning
Discharge planning begins on admission. It is important to identify the following as soon as possible after admission:
What medication the patient is taking;
Who is administering the medication to the patient;
What specific medication-related requirements does the patient have or potentially need;
Whether there are any adherence issues.
This information must be clearly documented on the drug chart and/or in the patient healthcare record. This is the responsibility of the medical team, supported by pharmacy and nursing staff.
Please refer to MSEPO-21090 Medicines Reconciliation Policy for further information.
For supporting adherence please refer to MSEPO-21084 Appropriate Use of Medication Compliance Aids Policy.
Prescribing discharge medication & documentation requirements

All patients discharged require an electronic discharge summary (unless a Trust approved alternative system is used); to include medicines for patients to take away (TTA). Wherever possible these should be written in advance of the discharge day to ensure a prompt discharge and free bed capacity.

When prescribing for discharge prescribers must provide a full description of the medicines with all particulars present as per any other prescription requirement. See Prescribing of Medicines Policy (or equivalent).
For Hospital at Home the TTA is written at the point of discharge from the Trust Hospital at Home service, and not at the point of the discharge from the ward.
Medication Changes (Discrepancies compared to medicines upon admission)

6.4.1 It is a requirement at discharge that all medication changes (and reasons why) are communicated in writing. This enables the GP, patient and carers to update their records for supporting ongoing medication needs.

6.4.2 Failure to provide accurate medication changes information risks patients unintentionally continuing on medicines which are no longer suitable for them – this can, and has, resulted in patient harm.
6.4.3 Similarly it is just as crucial that the GP, patient and carers are clearly informed in writing if there are no changes.

6.4.4 The prescriber must check the medicines reconciliation completed by pharmacy (where available) against the proposed discharge medicines. They must ensure all discrepancies are accounted for and the patient is safe. Any discrepancies
identified by pharmacy during medicines reconciliation is documented as a ‘Medicines Reconciliation' note on Wellsky ePMA or within the designated section on paper drug charts.

6.4.5 The prescriber must, for each medication change (newly started, stopped, or any changed dose/ formulation/ frequency etc.), list the change and the reason for the change on the discharge summary. Document this in the ‘Medication Changes' (or equivalent) section on the discharge summary. Pharmacy staff may also support this process as per pharmacy departmental procedure.
Ensure patients are informed and appropriately counselled (see section 12).
Patient's going back to their previous place of residence without health/social care/bridging support (i.e. NO changes to living status)

6.7.1 This means all patients discharged where any of the following apply:
To a nursing/care home;
To a bedded setting in community (e.g. community hospital);
Under the MSE bridging service (MSEBS);
Home with new health/social care support involving medication;
Any temporary residence not covered by the above

All medicines intended for patient to take after discharge
List all changes and give reasons for each change
All medicines intended for patient to take after discharge
Write: ‘No changes to regular medication – GP to continue supply as before'

data.text: * this denotes what is prescribed not necessarily for what will be supplied by the hospital to the patient, see sections below for supply arrangements.
Prescribing medication supplied via nurse/midwife TTA-packs
6.8.1 Section 6.8 applies to Southend Wellsky ePMA wards only.
6.8.2 Prescribing of medicines supplied as TTA packs for all other sites may be prescribed as above. Supply of TTA packs is covered in section 9.

6.8.3 Pre-labelled ‘TTA' packs for some very commonly prescribed medicines are available on wards to facilitate efficient discharge. Please consult the ward/unit- specific list before prescribing as these vary by specialty.
6.8.4 If a medicine is available on that ward as a TTA pack which exactly matches the requirement of the discharge prescription, it should be prescribed as a ‘TTA pack':
Ensure the correct discharge summary for speciality is selected before writing the discharge letter;
Under ‘Medication supplied as TTA packs' section, select from drop down menu within the discharge summary. Complete any ‘….' gaps with specific directions, where appropriate;
Do not prescribe on WellSky ePMA as this will result in duplication and delays to discharge;
Any non-TTA pack medicines (if any) must be prescribed on WellSky ePMA as per standard practice.
Short courses (i.e. antibiotics, steroids, acute pain analgesia)
The prescriber must include the exact duration required (i.e. number of days) for short courses of treatment e.g. antibiotics, steroids.
Controlled Drugs

6.11.1  Controlled drug prescriptions must comply with the legal requirements as outlined in Trust Controlled Drug Policy: MSEPO-20237. Pharmacy will only supply controlled drugs against a completed legal prescription document:
For patients with WellSky ePMA this will be Controlled Drug TTA Prescription Form available from the intranet.
For patients with paper drug charts, a signed copy of the printed discharge summary must be used.
Warfarin, acenocoumarol or phenindione
6.12.1 Patients continuing on these medicines must be formally referred to the anticoagulation clinic on discharge by the prescribing doctor, as per site process.
6.12.2 Patient must be dosed up to their clinic appointment and this clearly documented on the discharge paperwork and referral to the anticoagulation clinic.
6.12.3 Any bridging therapy with low molecular weight heparin must tally exactly with the referral and the prescription.
6.12.4 For any patients on these medicines who have therapy stopped the medical team must pass this information onto their usual anticoagulation clinic or practice that
normally monitors their INR and prescribes the drug. This information must be included in the patient's discharge letter by the discharging medical team.
Low molecular weight heparin (i.e. enoxaparin) / unfractionated heparin
6.13.1  Patients must have the following documented:
Dose and frequency;
Patient weight (in kilograms);
Current renal function (creatinine clearance specified);
Indication;
Duration of treatment. It is NOT acceptable to state ‘GP to review'. A clear plan for treatment must be indicated to ensure ongoing prescriptions happen, if required.
Methadone & sublingual buprenorphine for opiate substitution treatment
6.14.1 Patients must have the following documented to enable community services to continue supply of patient treatment:
Dose and frequency;
Time and date of last dose;
Any limited quantity supplied on discharge.

6.14.2 Ensure follow-up with the patient's ‘key worker' is arranged for continuation of supply in the community as pre-admission. This is essential to communicate dose changes. Document that this has been completed in the patient health record or Wellsky ePMA.

6.14.3 Note: It is standard practice not to supply any doses of these medicines on discharge. Patients should take their last dose on the ward witnessed by registered nursing/midwifery staff before discharge. In exceptional circumstances (i.e. bank holiday / Christmas) contact pharmacy directly for advice.
Non-medication items that are ‘prescribed'
6.15.1  If required, prescribe any other items which are not legally medicines but must be included to take post-discharge. Examples include:
Subcutaneous insulin needles (e.g. when newly started on insulin);
Artificial saliva gels;
Fluid thickener powders (in line with Speech & Language Therapist recommendations for discharge);
Nutritional supplements (in line with dietetic recommendations for discharge).
Pharmacy processing of TTAs

TTAs are requested using WellSky ePMA by entering a ‘Drug Order' note during pharmacy working hours. Non-WellSky areas must contact their pharmacist directly or liaise with dispensary. For out of hours, where the discharge is critical, the on- call pharmacist may be contacted.
For Basildon site areas not using WellSky ePMA please refer to CP/PC/00147 Standard Operating Procedure for the Electronic Discharge Process.
Pharmacy medicines check and authorisation of TTAs
7.3.1 Note: not all TTAs are authorised by a pharmacist and this differs according to site. Refer to site-specific discharge protocols in these instances.

7.3.2 Registered pharmacists will ensure all appropriate medication on the drug chart has been correctly transcribed over to the discharge prescription. Where registered pharmacy technicians are available they will support this process in accordance with pharmacy standard operating procedures.

7.3.3 Registered pharmacists will conduct a clinical screen (verification) of all medicines, looking at the prescription in its entirety in relation to the specific patient they are prescribed for. Verification will include:
Clinical assessment of appropriateness of doses, formulations, etc. in line with the patient clinical information available to them at the time;
Ensuring completeness and accuracy of monitoring details (i.e. for high-risk medicines) is communicated to the GP on the discharge summary.
7.3.4 Registered pharmacy professionals may, in line with their professional competency and pharmacy standard operating procedures:
Update discharge summaries with appropriate medicines information;
Undertake minor amendments to prescriptions:
Transcribe all medicines onto a discharge letter in specific circumstances where safe and appropriate to do so.

7.3.5 Any significant discrepancies in dosage, route, frequency or formulation are always clarified by contacting the prescriber. Any changes are then made in accordance with pharmacy standard operating procedures, or alternatively the prescriber is requested to amend the prescription themselves and inform pharmacy once changed.

7.3.6 Where available, the pharmacy team will support nursing in the undertaking of the review of the patient bedside locker. However, the discharging registered nurse remains responsible for the final bedside locker check (see section 8).

7.3.7 Where a pharmacist has clinically screened (verified) the medication on the drug chart and signed / dated, a registered pharmacy technician (assessed as competent) may authorise those items on the discharge medication list. This will be in accordance with pharmacy standard operating procedures.

7.3.8 If there is no registered pharmacy technician available or there are unscreened items, a pharmacist will be contacted to clinically screen the items and/or complete the accuracy check of the discharge medication list.
Process for supply of medication

7.4.1 Patients with regular repeat medication from the GP are very likely to have a system in place with their local community pharmacy for ongoing supplies (and deliveries in many cases). The hospital will not oversupply medication (i.e. based on ‘just in case') where an existing suitable supply arrangement for regular medicines is already in place.
7.4.2 The following chart outlines what supplies of medication will be made from pharmacy in specific circumstances:
NO NO NO YES
YES NO
* or equivalent service's bed (i.e. out of area service) NELFT community wards – Bayman, Thorndon and Mayfield EPUT community wards – CICC, Mountnessing Court
7.4.3 Patients in hospital for extended periods of time (greater than 28 days) will have all medicines supplied/ re-supplied from the hospital, in most instances.
When is discharge medication ready?

7.5.1 All TTAs requiring medication from pharmacy are entered onto the Prescription Tracking System (PTS) by pharmacy staff once the clinical verification process has been completed. Where prescriptions are received into pharmacy department awaiting processing (e.g. at weekends when there is a limited ward service) they are entered onto the PTS as ‘received'.
7.5.2 All ward-based staff supporting the discharge process must know how to access the PTS, and the ward manager is responsible for ensuring their staff have access and can use this system.

7.5.3 Once the medicines have been dispensed and checked by pharmacy they are either delivered to the ward at the allocated delivery times (during weekday daytime hours) or ward staff can check the PTS to check progress of the TTAs and collect from pharmacy when ready.
Ward-based dispensing of medicines (‘Pharmacy-On-Wheels' (POW))

7.6.1  Where medication is dispensed on the ward, the pharmacy team member must ensure it is against a valid prescription. If it has not been clinically screened by a pharmacist, they must be contacted to screen the prescription prior to the second check. Once screened, it must be second checked by a member of registered pharmacy or nursing staff, who is competency-trained and signed off to carry out the dispensing check. Both staff members must sign and date the prescription and write the amount supplied.
Issuing discharge medication (TTAs) to the patient
The discharging registered nurse/midwife is wholly responsible for the accuracy and completeness of medication issued to the patient on discharge from our care.
Tasks outlined in this section are the responsibility of the registered nurse/midwife.
Check the TTA is the final, complete and current version:
Check the date finalised by the doctor and pharmacy staff;
If it is not recent (e.g. within past 2 days) – is it still in date and remains correct?
Caution: if patient was not discharged and remained an inpatient there could have been changes to medicines not updated in the discharge prescription;
Are there changes on inpatient chart since the TTA was completed?
If unsure – refer to the doctor or pharmacy team to review the TTA.
Check the TTA contains appropriate prescription:
8.4.1 Refer to section 6.6 and 6.7 to check if all medicines need to be prescribed on discharge letter or not. These requirements are based on:
Is patient going to a new or temporary place of residence and/or with health/social care/bridging support (regardless if this is new care or not)? ;
How long has the patient been in hospital?
Have there been any changes to medication?
8.4.2 Details of any changes to medicines should be detailed on the discharge letter. This information is needed when checking medicines to give out on discharge.
8.4.3 If any information/medication is missing refer back to the prescribing doctor.
Process for discharge medication checks
8.5.1  Document the completion of the following process using a patient medication discharge check list (appendix 1) and file within the patient health record:
Complete and print two copies of the finalised TTA discharge prescription (one for patient health record, one for patient / carer), where possible;
Collate all medicines (see section 8.7);
Verify that the bedside medicines locker is empty;
Dispense any TTA packs required (see section 9);
Carryout final check of medicines (see section 8.11);
Document what has been supplied, sign and date copy of TTA, file in patient health record;
Provide discharge counselling (see section 12);
Follow up any identified adherence issues with the doctor and pharmacy team;
Document any relevant actions to be taken in the discharge lounge (if applicable).
Discharge medication types
8.6.1  All medicines given to a patient on discharge will be:
Individually dispensed by the pharmacy department for that patient and/or;
Supplied as a TTA pre-labelled pack and/or;
Patient's own drugs suitable for re-issue.
Where are medicines for discharge?
8.7.1 Medication for patient's discharge may be located in the following secure places:
Bedside medicine locker;
Ward fridge;
Patient's own/TTA section of the ward controlled drugs cupboard;
Locked TTA cupboard within drug room where medicines are too bulky to be stored in the bedside medicine locker.
8.7.2 Alternatively, patients have more at home:

It is not necessary to supply all the regular medicines that the patient was taking prior to admission for the patient on discharge. Most patients will have more supplies of medicines at home or awaiting collection/delivery from their usual community pharmacy (‘chemist'). Note this can be confirmed as having a regular repeat prescription arrangement from GP/community pharmacy;
It is not necessary to provide a new supply of any medicines if the ward pharmacy team considers that the patient has a sufficient quantity on the ward or at home;
The pharmacy team will detail this information on the drug chart or discharge summary (depending on site);
Patients should be discouraged from hoarding medicines or obtaining extra supplies on a “just in case” basis.
8.7.3 Nursing & midwifery staff must first ensure medication is not already on the ward or at home (as above) before requesting supplies from the hospital pharmacy.

8.7.4 Where is it verified that patients cannot access their own medicines at home or from community pharmacy then these may be ordered from the hospital pharmacy. Medicines must be specifically specified.
Patients where there have been no medication changes
8.8.1 Please also refer to section 6 for expectations of the prescribing doctor.

8.8.2 In these cases, the patient can take home any of the medications they brought into hospital with them. Collate all medication and check that all the medicines returned to the patient are for that specific patient.
Check medicines against medication changes on the discharge prescription
8.9.1 Please also refer to section 6 for expectations of the prescribing doctor.
8.9.2 If still in use, open the designated ‘medicines not currently in use' bag (where used) in the bedside medicine locker.
8.9.3 Review contents of the bag against the TTA:

Confirm that the contents are indeed ‘not in use' and have not been restarted on discharge. If restarted remove from bag and place with the rest of the patient's medicines – these must be checked as per section 8.11;

Discuss remaining contents of the bag with the patient, explaining they are discontinued or changed and their doctor has no longer wishes the patient to take that medicine/ strength/ formulation etc. as appropriate;
Obtain patient consent for removal of stopped/changed items and dispose as per Trust safe handling of medicines policy;

If patient does not consent, the contents of the bag may be given to the patient. The discharging registered nurse/midwife must ensure the patient has capacity and is fully aware of the implications and understands the reason/s why the medication has been stopped /changed and should not be taken;

Document all discussions with the patient in their health record (i.e. details of the discontinued or inappropriate medication that the patient was discharged with and what explanation was given as to why it must not be taken);
Never use the ‘medicines not currently in use' bag for current medication. This is unsafe because it may cause confusion for the patient/carer once they are at
home.
8.9.4 Actions to take for controlled drug changes or where there is a concern
In the case of a controlled drug or where there is concern in general, this must be discussed with a clinician looking after the patient and pharmacy if necessary.
If it is deemed unsafe or inappropriate for the controlled drug/medication to be returned to the patient, then this should be clearly documented in the medical notes and not returned to the patient.
TTA medication requirements
8.10.1 All medicines given to a patient on discharge must always be:
Labelled with directions for use on the dispensing label;
Be for that specific patient;
Match exactly that prescribed on the discharge prescription (TTA).
8.10.2 Never issue medication from the ward stock cupboard, this is unlabelled. Writing of anything on the container is illegal practice.
8.10.3 Never issue medication labelled for ‘inpatient use only' or if the dispensing label is without printed directions for use. This is illegal practice.
8.10.4 The discharging registered nurse/midwife must be aware of these requirements and recognise that breaking the law may face disciplinary action and affect their professional registration.
Check all TTA medication thoroughly against the current TTA prescription
8.11.1 Discharge medication checks may be performed by a registered nurse/midwife, registered pharmacist, registered pharmacy technician, or a competency-assessed discharge facilitator.

8.11.2 However, the final check of all medicines and sign off at the point of discharge is always the sole responsibility for the discharging registered nurse/midwife. This responsibility cannot be delegated.
8.11.3 Each medicine must be correctly labelled and the directions are clear, verifying the following matches the discharge prescription:
Patient name;
Drug name;
Strength;
Formulation;
Directions for use (dose, frequency, route etc.);
Within expiry date;
Minimum of 14 days' supply unless a fixed course of treatment;
8.11.4 If there are any discrepancies, discuss with the nurse/midwife in charge or the ward pharmacy team.
Provide any other required items (e.g. sharps bin for injection disposal) as appropriate and required written information (e.g. anticoagulation appointment and dosing – see section 13).
Issuing TTA packs
A TTA pack is a medicine that has been pre-labelled by the pharmacy for direct issue to patients.

In order to facilitate discharge, some clinical areas may be supplied with a limited range of pre-packed medicines for issue to individual patients. These can only be issued by the pharmacy department to the clinical area once mutually agreed.
TTA pack general principles

9.3.1 Requirements for TTA packs must be in agreement with the designated specialty pharmacist and ward manager (or equivalent), with approval from the relevant principal pharmacist (with divisional responsibility) and matron for oversight. Agreement for competency training for staff is agreed before consideration of supplying packs.
9.3.2 TTA packs must be stored in a designated locked medicine cupboard with temperature control meeting Trust standards. Refer to MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines.
9.3.3 TTA packs must only be supplied by a registered staff nurse/midwife, doctor, pharmacist or pharmacy technician against either a:
Discharge letter / valid hospital prescription (signed and dated) completed by a registered prescriber (which is confirmed as current if written 48 hours or more before discharge);
Patient Group Direction (PGD) only by staff authorised on that PGD (refer to MSEPO-20210 PGD Policy);
Patient Specific direction (PSD) entered into the patient medical notes by a prescriber (outpatient setting).
9.3.4 If in doubt as to the validity of any of the above to supply, pharmacy must be contacted for advice before supply.

9.3.5 When a registered nurse or midwife is engaged in dispensing, this represents an extension to their professional practice. All staff involved must be signed off as competent by the manager of the clinical area in the dispensing process and the expected standards of practice.
Selecting and checking TTA packs
9.4.1 Before selecting a pack ensure:
That the patient is not allergic to any drug prescribed as TTA packs i.e. do not issue co-amoxiclav to a patient with a penicillin allergy;
That any drug selected as a TTA pack is not already being taken by the patient i.e. do not issue paracetamol to a patient already taking co-codamol (which contains paracetamol);
9.4.2 The TTA pack of the correct drug, strength and form should be selected and checked that:
The pack is undamaged;
The pack is within expiry date (and will not expire before end of course);
The directions/frequency on the label are the same as on the prescription;
There is a sufficient quantity to be supplied.

9.4.3 If the TTA pack does not match all the above, then the TTA pack cannot be issued. TTA packs must never be tampered or altered in anyway. This is illegal. For example, the contents cannot be removed or the strips cut. (If the TTA pack contains more than the patient requires, the patient should be told to discard the remainder). If the directions on the label are different to those prescribed, never alter the label. If you do not have a TTA pack with the correct directions, then order this medicine from pharmacy on the TTA.
9.4.4 If the TTA pack is appropriate, then all blank spaces on the label must be completed. These typically include patient name, date, dose (if appropriate) etc. This is a legal requirement.
9.4.5 The TTA pack must be second independent checked by another registered member of staff (except as detailed in below) against the discharge letter/prescription to ensure that:
Correct drug, strength and formulation have been selected;
An appropriate quantity is being supplied;
The medication is in date and will remain in date for duration of course;
The frequency is correct (complete details if necessary);
The patient details have been filled in.
The second checker must countersign the prescription/discharge letter if correct (see below).

9.4.6 Exceptions for second-checking are doctors, registered pharmacists and registered nurses (band 6 and above) who are working in isolation where a second check is not possible. This must only be done in exceptional circumstances. The full responsibility of the accuracy of the dispensing is accepted by this individual.

Note: a single check whilst another nurse is on a break in the inpatient setting is unacceptable. A second check must be obtained after the break or from another available registered member of staff (e.g. registered pharmacy team).

In the Burns and Plastics directorate, a band 5 registered nurse (with agreed and signed off competencies) may supply TTA packs of topical medication for wound care without a second check when necessary. This only includes topical preparations for application to a wound and not by any other route. The full responsibility of the accuracy of the dispensing is accepted by the individual.
Documentation of issue of TTA pack
9.6.1 A record must be made of what TTA packs have been supplied.
9.6.2 Documentation must be clear and contain the following information:
PRINTED name of the responsible discharging nurse/midwife;
Signature of both the responsible nurse AND the second person checking;
Details of what was supplied e.g. 1x28 TTA pack;
Dated.

9.6.3 WellSky ePMA wards: endorse the printed copy of the discharge prescription against the drug grid or ‘TTA section' (or equivalent section depending on site). Retain copy of prescription with endorsements in patient health record.
9.6.4 Basildon/Brentwood sites using adult inpatient paper charts: endorse under noticeboard on page 16 of the ‘East of England' drug chart.
9.6.5 Patient Specific Direction (e.g. in patient health record): endorse supply next to the direction.
9.6.6 Paper prescription (e.g. Day case / Paediatric): endorse in designated supply section directly on prescription. Retain copy of prescription with endorsements in patient health record.
9.6.7 Patient Group Direction (e.g. outpatient clinic): Make an entry in the notes detailing exactly what has been supplied and state that ‘supplied in accordance with PGD [enter number of PGD].

TTA packs must then be supplied to the patient following the same checking process as for all other medication supplied (see section 9), this includes all patient checks (name, date of birth, NHS number).
Counselling must be provided for these medicines (see section 12).
Nurse/midwife-led processing of TTA
On certain approved wards and/or groups of patients, registered nurses/midwives are permitted by the principal pharmacist (with divisional responsibility) to process the discharge prescription.

Supply of medicines from the ward (using pre-labelled packs) must only be done by appropriately competency-trained registered nurses/midwives. This is determined by the ward manager who will be responsible for ensuring appropriate training has
been completed and documented. This scenario only applies to patients where regular medication is unchanged.

Once a discharge prescription has been completed, the discharging registered nurse MUST undertake the same level of checks as required in section 8. Any required TTA packs must be dispensed as per section 9.

Any discrepancies must be flagged to the prescriber for correction. Any medication no longer required must be removed from the patient's locker (with their permission) and disposed of in line with safe handling of medicines policy (or equivalent).

Patients admitted for less than 48 hours do not need their regular medication prescribed on the discharge letter. However a note for the GP must be added in the GP actions section i.e. ‘No changes to regular medication – GP to continue supply as before'.
Ensure that any drugs omitted pre or post-surgery are listed and a plan for restarting documented e.g. aspirin or antihypertensive.
Patients discharged with care/support
Returning to previous place of care

11.1.1 It is often undesirable for the hospital to supply additional medicines which are already available for that patient at the nursing/care home. Duplicate medicines sent to these establishments are often simply thrown away. Oversupply can also cause significant confusion reconciling medicines and may contribute to unintentional errors.

11.1.2 Ward and pharmacy staff must communicate with nursing/care home colleagues to ensure only genuinely required medicines are requested to be dispensed by the hospital pharmacy. The same checks are required when considering issuing TTA- packs to ensure there is not inappropriate oversupply to our patients.
Patients going to care setting away from their normal place of residence (e.g. temporary placement / new care home / bridging)
11.2.1 These patients require a full supply of all medicines to enable treatment to continue uninterrupted.
11.2.2 Patients that are discharged with bridging of care service (a temporary care plan until their full-time care is in place), also known as MSE bridging service (MSEBS) must have
all medicines prescribed on discharge summary, and
all supplied from the hospital.

This information is used by the bridging team to identify patient's current medication requirements. MSE bridging service patients are identified on care provision lists produced by hospital sites which discharging staff must refer to.
Medicine Compliance Aids
11.3.1  Consideration of Medicine Compliance aids must be undertaken in accordance with MSEPO-21084 Appropriate Use of Medication Compliance Aids Policy.
Discharge medicines counselling

Patient medicines counselling should be given for all new medicines prescribed, any changes made (irrespective of whether they are likely to be continued on discharge) and any existing medicines where a need for information is determined, or requested.
The primary responsibility for counselling lies with the prescriber. It is good practice to document that a discussion has taken place in the patient health record.

However, at discharge it must be ensured by the discharging registered nurse or midwife that all appropriate counselling is done. Registered pharmacy staff will also support this process, where possible, when involved in the discharge process.
At discharge, there should be a confirmation of patient understanding rather than delivery of large amounts of information.
Counselling covers a multitude of aspects relating to medicines but the key aspects that must be discussed are:
What the medicine is for;
How to take the medicines;
The side-effects to be aware of;
Any special storage conditions (if appropriate, e.g. fridge);
Any special disposal requirements (e.g. sharps bin for injections).
It is also important to counsel patients to return any medication they have at home which has been stopped, or where the dose has changed, to their community pharmacy.
In some cases a period of training for the patient may be necessary prior to discharge (i.e. device training for self-administration of injections).

Should the patient have questions or problems with their medicines, the discharging registered nurse/midwife may be able to answer the questions using their professional knowledge. However should there be any doubt the prescriber or pharmacy team must be contacted (including oncall pharmacist out-of-hours if needed) for advice and confirmation.
Verbal counselling should be supplemented with written information and signposting to other resources e.g. websites, as determined by discussions with the patient /
carers. This is particularly relevant when prescribing medicines off-licence or unlicensed medicines.
Provision of written information
All patients should receive a printed copy of their discharge prescription detailing their care and the discharge medication list.
Patients should receive medication-specific manufacturer patient information leaflets within the container of the medicine they have been supplied.
Hand-held information

Warfarin, acenocoumarol or phenindione patients must receive their anticoagulation clinic appointment and documentation of their dosing which will be processed by the pathology department. This must be documentation of the patient's latest INR result and their daily discharge dose until the date of their appointment'. Depending on site this may be updated in their anticoagulant booklet or as a printout slip.
Some patients may be commenced on high-risk medication where the Trust is mandated to provide written information (sometimes these are also known as a ‘passport' for that medicine).

Patients must be explained the purpose of the passport is to signpost to others if they become unwell of the medication they are taking, and that this should be shown in cases of emergency (i.e. paramedics, A&E admission etc.). Patients should be informed to keep on their person.
Examples of handheld information include:
Trust guidance leaflets (e.g. using opiates, referral to community pharmacy etc.);
Anticoagulation Booklets/Pack (‘Warfarin' yellow book);
Insulin Passport (credit-card sized);
Emergency Steroid Card (red edged credit card sized, different from ‘blue steroid cards);
Blue Steroid Card.
Training requirements
All staff involved must read this policy at induction.

Training for use of Wellsky ePMA for discharge prescribing is delivered via eLearning which must be completed by all prescribers and relevant pharmacy staff before they are given access to the system.
Training for use of electronic discharge platforms (varying by site) are delivered by the IT department at induction (prescribers), which may be delivered via eLearning.
For nursing/midwifery roles and support roles under the responsibility of the nurse/midwife, training is delivered via cascade on induction to the ward.
Monitoring and audit

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all prescribers, nursing and pharmacy of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

A discharging checklist may contain the following items. This checklist is not exhaustive. Basildon site: A version of this checklist is pre-printed within the Adult Inpatient Admission and Discharge Document (Form GNH020D).

table_items.text: Is there a discharge prescription written for this patient? If no arrange for this to be completed.

Perform a locker check: Remember CD cupboard, fridge, TTA cupboard if necessary Ensure all dispensed medication(s) agree with the TTA prescription i.e. Correct drug Correct dosage instructions Correct strength Minimum of 14 days supply Correct name on the label (unless exception exists e.g. Expiry date on medicine antibiotics) Manufacturer's information leaflet Bag issued to patient for medications

If any of the above were not correct then action is required before discharge e.g. Request medication to be relabelled from pharmacy Organise supply from pharmacy Issue a ward pre-labelled pack (TTA pack), if available
Any further action required in discharge lounge?
Document on drug chart / TTA prescription (depending on site) that locker medication has been issued to patient e.g. medicines issued to patient, date and sign.
Does the “medicines not currently in use” bag contain any medication?

If yes, discuss with the patient the reasons why the medication was separated e.g. medication stopped, changed or not prescribed. Following discussion with the patient: Have you removed any items from the bag for destruction? Have you obtained patient consent to do so? Have you documented in the patient's notes if any other action was taken?
Have you counselled the patient on their discharge medication?
Have you provided the patient with information about their medications?
Is the medication locker empty? (unwanted medicines disposed of correctly in line with policy).
